For those unable to attend, I wanted to share my prepared remarks for our #LaborDay rally in Albany yesterday:  Labor Day is a holiday at the heart of America’s character. It was meant to enshrine our values as a nation, a people that support our workers.    My heart tells me that our nation has forgotten some of the essential lessons this day was meant to celebrate.   Americans work a lot. According to the International Labour Organization (ILO), we work on average 137 more hours per year than Japanese workers, 260 more hours per year than British workers, and almost 500 more hours per year than French workers.     The promise of the labor movement was not just that America’s working parents could bring home a fair wage for a full day’s work. It was also that the gains of automation, of new advances that made America more productive, would lift our workers and not just those who employ them.   Instead, the wealthiest of the wealthiest, the wealthiest 1 percent OF the top 1 percent, have managed to soak up every spare cent of profit as our economy has become more automated. Meanwhile, workers are working longer hours, each worker’s productivity is up some 400% since 1950, but when it comes to making real economic gains, workers are being left behind.   Today, we live in a country where the wealthiest 1% possess 40% of all of our nation’s wealth, and the folks in the bottom 80% income bracket own just 7%.   Think about that for a moment. That great chasm between the investor class and the working class is often invisible. We don’t see the ultra-wealthy at the grocery store or during our daily commutes. They might as well live in a completely different country from the rest of us.   And things are getting worse. Several recent studies have shown that, since about 1980, the real income of the average working American family, accounting for inflation and all other costs, has been flat. In other words, the American worker hasn’t gotten a real raise since Ronald Reagan became president. Meanwhile, the income of the wealthiest 0.01% is around seven times what it was back then.    This is what we mean when we talk about a rigged economy, and it’s all happening on the backs of America’s working families. It’s what Bernie Sanders and Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump were all talking about in the 2016 election. But nobody is doing anything about it now.    I don’t want to make this too political. I really don’t. But I need to say this because this is Labor Day, this is why we celebrate this day as a national holiday.   One of the President’s first acts in office was to roll back a policy that gave working families with a home mortgage a break on their payments.    His healthcare bill would have thrown us back to a healthcare system that denied working families coverage for pre-existing conditions like “did you have acne as a kid”, “are you a woman of child-bearing age”, “have you ever had cancer.”    A healthcare system that condemned the sick and the unfortunate to lifetimes of crushing debt and often bankruptcy.    His bill would have slashed heartlessly at Medicaid, a program that covers half of all U.S. births and three quarters of America’s poorest children.    So much for family values.    And why? This is important, we need to ask that. Because he wanted to cut taxes for extremely wealthy families and for corporations. Trumpcare was a wealthcare bill.    I could go on and on, talking about his budget proposals that slash away at services for working families, for seniors, for children, for cutting-edge health research that would help protect our communities from Zika, combat heart disease and bring us forward in the cancer fight.    Programs that educate our kids earlier in their lives when that education makes the most difference. Programs that help people find and train for new jobs, that keep us out of wars and out of harm’s way.    None of those cuts will un-rig this economy. In fact they will do the opposite.    I believe the job of elected representatives, in an economy like this one, is to work toward improving the standard of living for all of our workers.   That starts with raising wages. And there are only two ways for workers to win higher pay—increasing the minimum wage and building strong unions.    In New York we know how important it is to have strong unions and pay workers a wage they can live on. That’s why we fought to raise the minimum wage to $15 an hour.    But in Washington and across the country, it’s too often the opposite. Congress hasn’t raised the federal minimum wage in eight years, and in many states, elected officials work hand-in-hand with big corporations to make sure that all the money goes to the rich folks, instead of to workers. They’re doing everything they can to keep wages low and gut union rights.    And here’s another shocking fact about our economy: nearly half of the U.S. workforce, some 64 million Americans, are paid less than $15 an hour today.    That’s not just a problem for workers. When so many millions of Americans are paid so little, barely enough to survive, we all pay the price. Those low wages end up costing taxpayers $150 billion every year in the form of needed public assistance for working families.     Our only shot at re-balancing the economy is to raise wages and to work to restore the strength and positive influence of our unions once more.   America needs its labor unions. They are on the front lines of every fight for workers’ rights, for safe working conditions and for the fair wages we need to re-balance this economy.   The workers in the jobs that dominate our state today – workers in hospitals, in healthcare, and the service sector – they need unions. I’m talking about strong organizations of workers with the bargaining power to make sure everyone sees their fair share of the profits.    Stronger unions will raise the wage floor and boost purchasing power for working people in every community, which will lead to more growth and a rising standard of living.    The fast food workers here today represent the bookends – the top and the bottom of the economic ladder -- within the service economy. We need these jobs to be good jobs, where people can pay for their basic needs and support a family.    I’m committed to standing with the Fight for $15, SEIU and all working people to make it easier for workers everywhere to join unions and bargain collectively for fair wages and fair treatment on the job. We need a strong economic agenda that ensures all Americans – not just the wealthy and powerful – have a voice again, and do well again.

Opening discussion on a set of four pieces of legislation being reviewed today by the Energy & Commerce Environment Subcommittee, where I serve as Ranking Member (most senior member of the minority).  Here are my remarks as prepared for delivery:  Thank you, Mr. Chairman.  Today’s legislative hearing will focus on four bills that seek to amend, and in my opinion, weaken, the Clean Air Act.  But first, I want to thank all of our witnesses for being here today. I certainly appreciate hearing the perspectives from small businesses that are responsible for implementing these EPA rules.  I also want to thank Dr. Bascom for being here on behalf of the American Thoracic Society. It is equally important that we hear about the medical and public health effects of delaying Clean Air Act rules.  Finally, I am happy to welcome back Ms. Alexandra Teitz, who served as Senior Counsel to this Committee for many years and is testifying on behalf of the Sierra Club.  The first two bills— the BRICK Act and the SENSE Act—  were considered by the Committee in the 114th Congress. Once again, I doubt the likelihood of either becoming law in the 115th.  I would recommend that instead we use our limited time to continue to build upon our bipartisan record of success.  H.R. 1917, the Blocking Regulatory Interference from Closing Kilns, or BRICK, Act, would delay implementation of EPA’s Brick and Structural Clay Products rule until all legal challenges are resolved.  Not only does this incentivize frivolous litigation to delay compliance, it creates a bad precedent that could be applied to other standards. Personally, I believe this can more effectively be resolved by the courts.  H.R. 1119, the Satisfying Energy Needs and Saving the Environment, or SENSE Act, would revise EPA’s Cross State Air Pollution Rule, or CSAPR and Mercury and Air Toxics rule, or MATS, to allow power plants that burn waste coal to emit higher levels of sulfur dioxide and hydrogen chloride.  New York has seen the benefits of the Clean Air Act’s good neighbor provision. I saw the damage caused by acid rain, particularly near my district in the #Adirondacks, and much of it was due to out-of-state pollution.  CSAPR requires certain states to reduce their annual emissions of sulfur dioxide. This rule has been extremely effective– preventing tens of thousands of premature deaths and hospitalizations, and millions of missed days of work or school each year.  CSAPR uses a phased-in approach to achieve emissions reductions, where emissions allowances decrease over time.  But the SENSE Act would hold allowances for waste coal constant.  It is worth noting that states already have the ability to create their own implementation plans, which could include shifting allowances. This bill will impede on states’ rights to determine the best path for reducing emissions.  Ultimately, I do not believe we should be giving any fuel source special treatment on reducing air pollution, especially when other power plants are expected to meet similar requirements.  H.R. 453, the Relief from New Source Performance Standards Act of 2017, would delay the Step Two compliance date by three years for three categories of wood-fueled heaters.  I would note that there are companies already compliant with EPA’s 2020 standard.  Finally, H.R. 350, the Recognizing the Protection of Motorsports Act of 2017, would exempt motor vehicles used solely for competition from penalties for altering a vehicle that results in increased emission of air pollutants.  I am concerned how broadly this bill is written. It would create a loophole that would make it even more difficult for EPA to regulate manufacturers that produce emissions control defeat devices for vehicles. Ultimately, delaying or undermining rules that seek to reduce hazardous air pollutants is not good for Americans.  The scientific, medical, and public health communities have ample evidence that polluted air is a threat to our health, particularly for vulnerable populations.  We also know that pollution can be a tremendous drag on our economy and productivity— causing respiratory illnesses, costly hospitalizations, missed school and work days, and even premature deaths.  The Clean Air Act has been about making progress over time. The longer we delay new standards, the longer our constituents are forced to live with unhealthy levels of air pollution.  Our country can do better than the status quo, and in recent years, the EPA has worked hard to develop protections that will continue the decades-long trend of improving our nation’s air quality.  So I want to reiterate my initial concerns with the bills before us today.  I look forward to hearing from our witnesses, and I yield back.

Spoke this morning at a hearing on the terrible opioid epidemic facing our country. My full remarks as prepared for delivery:  Thank you, Mr. Chairman.  We are a nation in crisis. The opioid epidemic is wreaking havoc in our communities at an unprecedented scale, with the CDC estimating 64,000 dead from drug overdoses in 2016, an astonishing 21 percent increase from the previous year.  This public health disaster is costing us more lives annually than at the peak of the AIDS epidemic – as many lives as gun violence and traffic accidents combined.   If this Congress doesn’t find additional solutions to turn the tide on the opioid epidemic, we will be complicit in this American tragedy.  I’m here today to offer two such legislative solutions.  First, I introduced the Addiction Treatment Access Improvement Act, H.R. 3692, with my good friend Congressman Ben Ray Lujan. This legislation would expand access to medication-assisted treatment by allowing certified nurse midwives and other advanced practice registered nurses to prescribe buprenorphine. In addition, this legislation would codify the 2016 rule that allowed physicians to treat up to 275 patients with buprenorphine and eliminate the sunset of a provision that allows non-physician providers to prescribe MAT.  The Addiction Treatment Access Improvement Act would particularly benefit pregnant and postpartum women who are struggling with addiction and improve outcomes for the over 13,000 infants that are born each year with neonatal abstinence syndrome.   Despite the expansion of medication-assisted treatment in Comprehensive Addiction and Recovery Act, there is still a significant shortage in treatment capacity, resulting in individuals waiting months or years to receive effective addiction treatment. Only 20 percent of patients who need treatment for opioid use disorder are currently receive it.   The Addiction Treatment Access Improvement Act would address this treatment gap and save lives. This committee should act on this bipartisan legislation without delay.  The second bill I’d like to discuss is the Medicaid Reentry Act, H.R. 4005. This legislation is a targeted attempt to address the problem of overdose deaths that occur post-incarceration.   Studies have shown that individuals who are released back into the community post-incarceration are roughly 8 times more likely to die of an overdose in the first two weeks post-release compared to other times. The risk of overdose is elevated during this period due to reduced physiological tolerance for opioids among the incarcerated population, a lack of effective addiction treatment options while incarcerated and poor care transitions back into the community.   The Medicaid Reentry Act would grant states flexibility to restart Medicaid coverage for Medicaid-eligible individuals 30-days pre-release. By allowing Medicaid benefits to restart prior to release, states would be able to more readily provide effective addiction treatment pre-release and would allow for smoother transitions to community care, reducing the risk of overdose deaths post-release – striking an overall wiser use of scarce Medicaid dollars.  Let me be clear, this legislation would not expand Medicaid eligibility in any way, it would simply grant states new flexibility to restart an individual’s Medicaid benefits 30-days earlier than allowed under current law. This increased flexibility would dovetail with innovative reentry programs already being championed by Republicans and Democrats in states across the country and would give individuals reentering society a fighting chance to live a healthier, drug-free life.  Let me just end with an urgent plea for action and bipartisanship. I know that many of the ideas that this committee will hear today would, in normal times, be met with the typical partisan objections and end up stuck in a procedural morass.   These are not normal times. When your house is on fire, you don’t look to see whether the firemen are wearing red or blue uniforms before they turn the hoses on.   If we are truly going to make a difference in this crisis and save lives we have to have a big heart and an open mind.    I thank my colleagues for their time and for their consideration of the legislation I have presented.

In a research library capacity, we’re thinking about large datasets, the use of high-power broadband is needed to access those large datasets. I rise to congratulate Amsterdam radio legend Sam Zurlo on his retirement this week.  For 64 years, Sam’s voice has greeted the residents and visitors of Montgomery County, New York Sam has been working in broadcasting since 1953.   Now at 82, he hosts the longest-running talk show in the history of the county.  Sam’s broadcasting career was born from his service with Armed Forces Radio in Germany where he delivered a nightly broadcast for three years.   Sam also worked as a print journalist for the Schenectady Gazette for some 35 years.   Decade after decade, his distinctive voice has been the catalyst for free and open debate.  He has brought an air of familiarity, and of community to our humble corner of Upstate New York.  Listening to conversations about current events with Sam has always made the abstractions of politics a little more real.   Sam’s personality has inspired many and brought light, comfort and connection to countless neighbors and friends.  Thank you to Sam Zurlo for his years of exceptional work and a legendary career in local journalism, and best wishes for an equally special retirement.
